Expectation1: Complete any assignments or tasks given by the mentor.
Situation1: The mentor suggested some optional reading and the informal deadline is weeks away.
Expectation2: Ensure compliance with safety and regulatory standards
Situation2: A recently updated standard will apply to the upcoming release, and evidence of conformity is required
Story:
I sat at my desk, the hum of the office fading into the background as I stared at the two open tabs on my screen. One was the dense, technical document my mentor had suggested I read—optional, he’d said, but I knew he expected me to be prepared for our next meeting. The other was the new safety standard, just released, that would soon govern our next product launch. As an engineer, I was responsible for making sure our design met every requirement, and the deadline for submitting evidence of compliance was looming.

My mentor’s words echoed in my mind: “Take your time, but I think you’ll find this reading really valuable.” I wanted to impress him, to show I was committed to learning. But the pressure from my engineering team was mounting. “We need your analysis on the new standard by Friday,” my manager had said, his tone leaving no room for delay.

I felt torn, the weight of both expectations pressing down on me. Should I dive into the reading to honor my mentor’s trust, or focus on the urgent compliance work that my team—and the company—was counting on? My fingers hovered over the keyboard, heart pounding, as I wrestled with what to do next.
